page.title: 17BUCTON CASTLE & ROMAN ROADS
page.content: High on the eastern hills overlooking the River Tame is Bucton. Here are the remains of an early encampment. Although generally described as a Roman Castle; because of its oval shape,its origins are more likely to be early British, probably used by sun-worshippers. The traditional rectangular Roman camp shape is missing, although Romans definitely occupied the site, taking advantage both of its strategic position, and its approximate midpoint between their camps at{Melandra}near Glossop, and{Castleshaw}above Delph. The site commands views over the south part of Lancashire, the greater part of Cheshire, and some considerable distance over the Yorkshire moorlands.
